title: Here’s how a move towards impeaching Trump might hurt investors, says Allianz
text:
As the dust settles on some startling political headlines, stock futures for Wednesday indicate investors are rattled, but not running for the hills just yet.

That may be because many believe a President Trump impeachment inquiry, news of which broke Tuesday, will go nowhere thanks to a Republican-held Senate. This is also a stock market that’s well-seasoned when it comes to political headlines.

Still, there is risk that the process gets more worrying for investors, possibly even delaying a trade deal if China uses the upheaval to bargain harder.

Read: How the top U.S. newspapers are covering the impeachment inquiry into Trump

Diving right in, our call of the day, from Neil Dwane, global strategist at Allianz Global Investors, warns investors may get hurt even if the moves towards impeachment fizzle out.

“Impeachment is unlikely to work as it needs both Houses to align,” Dwane told MarketWatch in an interview. “But this ruins any civility into the next election, so we should expect POTUS to fight ugly through 2020 as well.”

Such partisanship could “undermine executive and investor confidence in the U.S. economy,” at least for now, hurting investments and employment, he said. And if you’ve got Washington gridlock, then chances of a U.S. recession are higher, which may not be saved by lower interest rates, Dwane warned.

Amid the fallout, international investors might get rattled and become less keen on U.S. assets such as the dollar and U.S. Treasurys. Impeachment talk also may hurt the long running U.S.-China trade negotiations as he said that country “will not bother to do a trade deal as it does not know who to deal with.”

Investors can also expect to see a more “polarized electorate’ similar to what we are seeing in the U.K., and with that “expect more volatility as sentiment swings to and fro with the politicians and the polls” warns Dwane.

The strategist hasn’t been a fan of equities, notably U.S. stocks since gains in the first quarter, due to concerns over Trump and trade negotiations and fears of a possible recession. “We think you still have to take some risk on returns, but we don’t think we’re in a risk-on environment and certainly not with the Fed reluctantly lowering rates,” he said.

For the S&P 500, Dwane thinks the roughly 18% year-to-date gain is “pretty much as good as it gets.

The market

The S&P SPX, +0.14%, Dow DJIA, +0.28% and Nasdaq COMP, +0.06% have opened slightly firmer. Oil CLX19, -2.46% down, while gold GCZ19, -0.32% is slipping and the dollar DXY, +0.39% is up.

The going has been tough for Europe SXXP, -1.10% and Asia stocks ADOW, -0.72% as well.

The chart

Bitcoin BTCUSD, -1.99% dived sharply late Wednesday, and some, like Slope of Hope blogger Tim Knight sees a $7,000 level on the horizon. Here’s our chart of the day that shows how a week’s trading has deteriorated for the cryptocurrency which is down again this morning:

Falling off a cliff?

The buzz

Merger talks between Philip Morris PM, +6.82% and Altria MO, +0.98% have been called off, and the tobacco companies said they will instead focus on launching a smokeless tobacco product in the U.S.. Shares of both are up.

Nike NKE, +5.43% shares are up after the sportswear maker beat Wall Street forecasts and reported strong China sales.

Would-be McDonald’s employees can now use Amazon’s AMZN, +0.18% Alexa or Alphabet-owned GOOGL, -0.28% Google Assistant to apply for a job at the fast-food giant.

Data-measurement firm Comscore SCOR, +0.45% will pay $5 million to settle with the Securities and Exchange Commission over charges it fraudulently inflated revenue, while former CEO Serge Matta was also penalized. Neither Matta nor the company confirmed or denied those charges.

The data calendar is empty for Wednesday, but we’ll hear from a bunch of Federal Reserve officials — Chicago, Kansas City and Dallas Presidents Charles Evans, Esther George and Robert Kaplan, alongside Fed Gov. Lael Brainard, who will testify to the House Financial Services panel,
